content:
The "Stop, Observe, Ask, and Respond to Health and Wellness Act of 2018" establishes a training program for healthcare and social service providers on human trafficking. The program aims to educate providers on identifying and responding to human trafficking situations. The Health and Wellness Training Program includes authorized initiatives such as engaging stakeholders, providing technical assistance to grantees, and developing a methodology for data collection. The Health and Wellness Training Program aims to develop a reliable methodology for collecting data on human trafficking victims and integrating training for health care and social service providers for various forms of abuse. Grants may be awarded for training programs. The Health and Wellness Training Program aims to train health care and social service providers to identify and assist human trafficking victims, implement best practices for reporting and communicating with law enforcement, refer victims to appropriate agencies, and provide evidence-based care. Consideration is given to geography when awarding grants. The Health and Wellness Training Program awards grants based on geography, demographics, types of human trafficking cases, and provider profiles. The Secretary collects data on entities receiving grants, providers trained, and facilities. The Secretary collects data on the total number of facilities and health care professional organizations operating under the Stop, Observe, Ask, and Respond to Health and Wellness Training Program. An annual report is submitted to Congress while best practices and procedures are shared on the Department of Health and Human Services website. Entities receiving grants must adhere to best practices for activities related to human trafficking. The term 'human trafficking' is defined as 'severe forms of trafficking in persons'. $4,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2020 to 2024 to carry out this Act.
